author: bridge-bot
content: <julianzma> Could you explain what the value is of such a receipt for a user if there were no collusion between committee members? Because if there is no collusion, then there should be at least one IL committee member or the proposer that includes the transaction so it is not clear what the proposer gains with such a receipt

author: potuz
content: the user does not want to send their transaction in public

author: bridge-bot
content:
<julianzma> Users typically do not send their transactions in public because they are MEV-related and they want to prevent things like sandwiching.

Sending a transaction in private to an inclusion list committee member does not provide these services that users who send private transaction want. Transactions are made public after they are included in an inclusion list so they can, for example, still be sandwiched.

author: potuz
content: you are not sending the tx to an inclusion committee member, you are sending it to a centralized preconfer, who will buy the rights from the IL members,

author: potuz
content: this market makes sense only if the centralized preconfer is also the block builder, which in Ethereum L1 is highly likely to happen since there's only 2 builders

author: bridge-bot
content: <julianzma> Then still the transaction becomes public as soon as the IL is broadcasted (re @InclusionList_bot: <potuz> you are not sending the tx to an inclusion committee member, you are sending it to a centralized preconfer, who will buy the rights from the IL members,)

author: potuz
content: that is fine, because by the time the tx is public you have a commitment for inclusion which is what you wanted

author: potuz
content: sending it in the public mempool makes the transaction public before you get this commitment
